219EDB5FCA9F4E6391C63EC829FBB2D4.description: Examine the impact and significance of the War of 1812 (e.g., nationalism, Dolly Madison, the Star Spangled Banner, the U.S. Flag, borders, Battle of New Orleans)

0E5FA6EEEAFD4C28909D478C34C57921.description:
Evaluate how early presidents influenced the development of the new nation
(e.g., Washington’s Farewell Address, Marbury vs. Madison, Embargo Act, Louisiana Purchase, Lewis and Clark, banking)

75E3158F90D847679F3708D15A9029C7.description: Examine short- and long-term effects of the drafting and signing of the U.S. Constitution

09ACA2081F5E4F809AC6E06F1D9635DB.description: Analyze the process of creating a single country from a loose association of states (e.g., weakness of the Articles of Confederation, currency, State vs. Federal control, military)

EBE2BA67066045A3B9269535C7F16F58.description: Analyze the significance of various battles and military leaders during the American Revolution

2A4F9A3876FC44938B2BCF079B214F38.description:
Examine the significance of the drafting and signing of the Declaration of Independence
(e.g., key political concepts, Olive Branch Petition, origin of concepts, role and impact of severing ties with Great Britain)

3675684B695D400A8E82A104CA32E53F.description: Evaluate how individuals and groups influenced the American Revolutionary movement (e.g., Thomas Paine, Benjamin Franklin, Patrick Henry, George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, King George III, Sons and Daughters of Liberty)

E9B1DEB7B6154CFBB1CEDDEDA491B124.description: Analyze causes and ideas leading to the American Revolution (e.g., French and Indian War, Stamp Act, Intolerable Acts, Boston Tea Party, independence, representation, liberty)

16680F5C19064B98B6CD953A857CA2FF.description:
Analyze the Revolutionary movement from multiple perspectives using primary and secondary sources
(e.g., loyalists, patriots, Native Americans, slaves)

FADDCAF8E7C04EE5BA0E4E735FC25499.description: Research the development of the colonies by generating compelling and supporting questions to guide inquiry (e.g., Why did people settle where they did? How did they solve problems? Was life better in the colonies than in England? Was life better in some colonies than others? How were patterns of settlement influenced by beliefs, economics, and geography?)

E3E59A65936142E19351DB8BBC2CAB43.description: Evaluate the economic and cultural effects of indentured servitude and slavery in the New England, middle, and southern colonies from multiple perspectives

590436D120784627A6F724B59160424D.description:
Compare the social, economic, political, and geographic development of the New England, middle, and southern colonies
from multiple perspectives using a variety of sources
(e.g., Native Americans, Africans, colonists, indentured servants, colonial leaders, Europeans, farmers, merchants)

25576E56B450400EBE21912062C409C8.description: Evaluate short- and long-term effects of European exploration and settlement in the Americas and Arkansas from multiple perspectives (e.g., Roanoke, Jamestown, disease, conflict)

B03065002CD347A19573212E277D967E.description: Examine reasons for European exploration in the Americas from multiple perspectives (e.g., trade, religion, colonies, spheres of influence, wealth)

8B594ABF94C944ECA249005D7E8AE472.description: Compare characteristics (e.g., dwellings, culture, beliefs, land use, food, clothing) of major pre-Columbian people groups within North America using a variety of sources (e.g., mound builders, cliff dwellers, Southwest, Great Plains, Pacific Northwest, Woodland peoples)

84697429DDED48C483D42BC03C6B9175.description:
Develop claims about pre-Columbian societies in North America by analyzing artifacts, artwork, charts, graphs, digital, and
print sources

6B9CED92CAB84C83A52BDBE7365CD9CE.description:
United States Beginnings Through 1820s - Students will analyze key historical periods; patterns of change over time; and ways
people view, construct, and interpret the history of the United States.

3B5E8AC2D20F4E72BA74E183F9EED77D.description: Analyze cooperation within communities during and after natural and human-made disasters (e.g., disease, famine, weather phenomena, war)

8E2053B20A5E40EC98F16DE6C4E177B7.description:
Explain how interactions with nearby and distant places have
changed the spatial patterns of economic activities over time
(e.g., explorers, trade routes, triangular trade)

A6068E2E169D4566AAB8D83CBB21BF45.description: Global Interconnections - Students will compare global places and regions and the connections between them.

C400224975E04DF3B40B331D9A3F92D0.description: Examine reasons for population shifts in early America and the effects on various regions

ED0140C6A23B492FA0838BD8F96E914A.description: Examine effects of environmental and cultural characteristics on the distribution and movement of people, goods, and ideas using multiple sources of information (e.g., trade routes, water ways, geographic barriers, accessibility)

0EB3FAAA04E34ED8B3D78102E2D36D58.description:
Examine relationships between human settlements and
movements and the location and use of natural resources in
the early Americas
(e.g., early people groups, Native Americans, Westward
expansion)

9E27E9B091D941B19BCFD59722B7C4A5.description: Spatial Patterns and Movement - Students will interpret the spatial characteristics and patterns of human settlement

F7190E426E8E4DE5A8E2493984A26E50.description:
Analyze ways climate and environmental characteristics
influenced where groups lived and how they adjusted to the
environment

0FA05F6107024162B95FC239C0AC60C0.description: Analyze ways cultural characteristics influenced population distribution in the early Americas through the postRevolutionary period

E58A847B30624672917797BE05DE5959.description:
Analyze effects of human-generated changes on the
physical environment in places and regions over time from
early America to the 1820s

F9F102F5B5FC40B2A2A6E761DB5C7C37.description: Human-Environment Interaction - Students will analyze the interaction between humans and the environment.

4F49963DC77742E287CF4A9179065477.description:
Synthesize information from a variety of sources to construct
maps and other geographic representations

C0315C132177461DB9DB4869453FA082.description: Explain relationships between physical and human characteristics and changes over time using a variety of geographic representations

6D3F4DEED06D4BA0880485F5CE9BB6F1.description:
Describe locations of societies and their cultural and
environmental characteristics within the early Americas
through the 1820s using geographic representations of
different scales

F3AFB75A58FD442085DE8DB0A898660A.description: Geographic Representations - Students will use geographic representations and skills to become geographically informed citizens.

73BC48B283FB4CF9AEB6C6E4D940A79D.description: Explain effects of increasing economic interdependence on different groups within participating nations (e.g., conflict, competition, cooperation, increased wealth, quality of life)

D9A23E2BEC1142F8A5A911B9E40F8A46.description:
Explain ways trade leads to increasing economic
interdependence among countries
(e.g., slave trade, triangular trade, manufactured goods,
agriculture)

2DB5BA0E14B14A21B02AC876CF9492CF.description: Global Economy - Students will analyze economic interdependence within a global economy

E9EAB01EBF5744ED9F5F81E1B855E7DD.description:
Evaluate effects of war and conflict on communities from the
colonial period to the early 1800s using economic factors

02E438D5A7EA45208E2570E2861E81C4.description: Discuss effects of unemployment, inflation, and price stability on the economy of the United States through the Revolutionary period

401ED3BFF9F34CD3BB53B11AA41C5774.description:
Explain ways state and federal governments pay for the
goods and services they provide

E613735458104854894AEBB8D410A757.description: Examine roles of early financial institutions on the economy of the United States

38A7771B3302485FA349E69A664F633B.description:
Analyze the forms and purposes of currency in early America
through the Revolutionary period

8C1E2B81FE484C0BAD00A433E986F2FD.description: Growth and Stability - Students will evaluate economic growth and stability.

A43796D32AB14349A66A2B748399B0A7.description:
Evaluate the development of a free market system (e.g.,
mercantilism, property rights, free enterprise)

6AE84A81D2F94D21B7EB3E6D0C1373AB.description:
Examine ways human, natural, and capital resources were
organized to produce and deliver goods and services in precolonial
America through the Revolutionary period
(e.g., trade companies, joint stock companies,
entrepreneurs, merchants)

099A724512B74F618AF0938257ABFE6F.description:
Examine ways a diverse labor force affected economies in
early America

24BA88F85E994BA38FB77D177EAE1F03.description:
Exchange and Markets - Students will analyze the exchange of goods and services and the role of producers, consumers, and
government in the market place.

597B29C3F14B46F7B093627B1C84433D.description:
Analyze historical developments in pre-colonial America
through the Revolutionary period using models of economic
decision making
(e.g., exploration, colonization, taxation, the American
Revolution, the new nation)

C31954C792F54A6DB9A6F7118FCC4979.description:
Explain ways trade-offs have allowed societies to get the
most out of scarce resources

96672B6E338F470CB95AAB8122C7C6FE.description: Economic Decision Making - Students will analyze economic decision making.

AB10F378CCF84C7E99F4E3CD03EB17D9.description:
Explain the development of policies to address public
problems at the local, state, and federal level

B4028D7F0C7849FB88FFC46616D7336F.description:
Evaluate ways rules and laws change society and reasons
why people change rules and laws at the local, state, and
federal levels

49D0379D882E43B289B88C008543C11C.description:
Compare the process for creating rules and laws at the local,
state, and federal levels

A47E49AB120A4092B946DAEB98628D86.description:
Processes, Rules, and Laws - Students will analyze the sources and functions of laws as well as the process of making and
amending laws.

2357AC281F424CC895F1345DB664BE12.description:
Examine actions of individuals and groups that illustrate civic
virtues at the local, state, and national level

89054F157591456F94B59D1AB03C24DB.description:
Analyze rights, responsibilities, and privileges of citizens and
non-citizens in the United States

2D7437807B9A4127B1DCFEFB643F56C4.description:
Demonstrate proper etiquette for the Arkansas and American
Flags

AF3B91F581AE492DA1576682682BB45F.description:
Evaluate various ways of fostering citizenship and civic
virtues

C8A602D4DEF344E59E011825B6FD9024.description: Participation and Deliberation - Students will analyze civic rights, roles, and responsibilities

6FF4058B755E42DF9AE203DA94FD9FF0.description:
Examine how social organizations and institutions make
rules and create responsibilities
(e.g., workplace, families)

A7D9AF5676F64D4B9AACD7C01BA61C7F.description:
Explain origins, functions, and structure of different systems
of government, including those created by the Arkansas and
U.S Constitutions

2726096587394BE18671DE5EB56BDAC9.description: Examine the three branches of federal and state government including checks and balances and separation of powers

32D0D44DD4E642DF8D1CC97B18DE042C.description: Examine foundational documents of the United States government (e.g., Magna Carta, English Bill of Rights, Mayflower Compact, Declaration of Independence, Articles of Confederation, U.S. Constitution)

76C17DF228D54FEF8D7BDF2880E2FE5A.description:
Civic and Political Institutions - Students will analyze the impact of origins, structures, and functions of institutions on society and
citizens.
